awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will address fundamental problems concerning solutions to partial differential equations that are used to model the dynamics of plasmas and fluids in physics. The focus will be on studying the fundamental law of physics to predict mixing and relaxation of macroscopic quantities in the large time. The project will contribute new mathematical techniques to the theory of partial differential equations and the field of mathematical physics, dynamical systems, and applied mathematics. In addition, it will advance our understanding of turbulence in plasma physics and fluid dynamics. The project provides training opportunities for graduate students and other early-career researchers.
 
The project seeks to advance beyond the study of mixing and relaxation, or Landau damping, in plasma physics and fluid dynamics, and to address fundamental stability problems concerning the behavior of solutions with limited regularity. The fundamental equations to be studied include the classical Vlasov models in plasma physics and the Euler and Navier-Stokes equations in fluid dynamics. The goal is to provide new insights into Landau damping and mixing in plasmas and fluids. The main approaches will involve mathematical techniques from spectral theory, resolvent analysis, Fourier analysis, dispersive PDEs, probability, and statistical physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project resolves completely the linear Landau damping for kinetic models including Vlasov-Poisson and Vlasov-Maxwell systems that are widely used in plasma physics. The new findings includes (1) the discovery of survival threshold that completely characterizes the linearized dynamics of a plasma, (2) the resolution of the inviscid limit problem and the boundary layer theory in general domains, (3) the development of Landau damping in quantum mechanics, and (4) the establishment of a new nonlinear framework to study plasma oscillations and to resolve the particle-wave nonlinear interaction. The project provides new frameworks and techniques to study the large time dynamics of both classical and quantum particles. The new framework provided was the first such a framework to study oscillations in the physical phase space, and will likely have an impact in several other contexts where nonlinear interaction between particles and oscillatory waves is present. 

The project attracts and trains graduate students in the field of Mathematical Physics through (1) organizing the summer school series in mathematical physics, (2) founding and running the Snapshots in Mathematical Physics group at Penn State, (3) offering new graduate topics courses, and (4) directly training and supervising PhD graduate students. The project maintains strong international collaboration with researchers in France and Germany. 

The outcomes of the project have been recognized by the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics as "extensive and deep contributions to the mathematical theory of the dynamics of gas and fluids" through the 2022 T. Brooke Benjamin Prize in Nonlinear Waves awarded to the PI.
